awd_titl_txt: Nanoscale Control over Surface Functionalization by Molecular Layer Deposition
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry (MSN) Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Stacey Bent and her research group at Stanford University are developing new chemistries for carrying out processes that deposit a molecular layer of material on a surface (molecular layer deposition (MLD)).  These layers are nanometer-sized (one billionth of a meter) and contain organic molecules in a very thin film. Organic thin films on surfaces are important because they provide ways to tune the electronic, chemical and mechanical properties of materials, with applications ranging from nanoelectronics to biomedical devices to catalysis. The research program studies the fundamental process by which the layers are added to the surface as well as the resulting organic films. The fundamental understanding gained from this work helps introduce a new tool-kit for attaching thin films with useful and tunable properties to solid materials. The Bent group provides mentorship and training to graduate students and undergraduate researchers.  The team hosts high school teachers in a diverse, multidisciplinary environment. STEM undergraduates have the opportunity to work in small, energy-related companies through a summer internship program that Professor Bent helped initiate.

The project contributes new methods for the controlled synthesis of functional thin films at solid surfaces by expanding the MLD technique in two principal directions. The research explores ways in which solution-based approaches can inform new synthetic strategies for organic MLD with the use of nanometer-thick films of liquids at the surface.  These films mimic solvent effects on surfaces. The team expands MLD approaches to create novel, hybrid surface assemblies, including hybrid materials based on metal sulfides and metal nitrides. The film synthesis is closely integrated with characterization studies that elucidate MLD mechanisms and both microscopic and macroscopic film properties. Experimental and theoretical approaches are undertaken to uncover information such as the extent of reaction, film structure, the presence of long-range order, chain orientation, film stability, and optical and electrical properties in the interfacial assemblies. The studies aim to answer fundamental questions about growth mechanisms and the relationship between film structure and interface properties in MLD. Taken together, the research may lead to new approaches to create interfacial functionality for a wide range of systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This grant focused on development of new chemistries for carrying out molecular layer deposition (MLD) of nanoscale organic-based thin films. Organic-based functional layers at surfaces are important because they provide a way to tune the electronic, chemical and mechanical properties of a substrate, with applications ranging from microelectronics to biomedical devices to catalysis. The research program studied the fundamental process by which the layers are added to the surface with an emphasis on both organic and hybrid organic-inorganic thin films.

The project contributed new methods for controlled synthesis of functional thin films at solid surfaces by expanding the MLD technique through two principal directions. The work introduced a method called ionic layer assisted MLD, in which a nanometer-thick film of an ionic liquid at the substrate surface facilitates MLD by mimicking solvent effects and allowing addition of a catalyst to the MLD process. Proof of concept was provided in the successful thin film vapor deposition of polyetherketoneketone (PEKK). The research also expanded the ionic liquid technique to atomic layer deposition (ALD), demonstrating ALD of SnO using just the mild precursors tin acetylacetonate and water, avoiding the need for a stronger counter-reactant like ozone.

This work also developed several new hybrid MLD chemistries, including for thin film synthesis of materials containing either molybdenum or zinc metal and organosulfur groups. By characterizing the behavior of these deposited thin films, some of the resulting sulfur-based films were found to be more stable in air than their oxygen-containing analogs. The research also showed that the optoelectronic properties of hybrid molybdenum organosulfur thin films can be tuned by changing the organic linker, with films containing aromatic linkers having significantly greater conductivity than those containing aliphatic linkers. An aluminum metal-based hybrid material was also developed through the introduction of a robust, three-precursor MLD process that incorporates a desirable acrylate, methyl-methacrylate (MMA), together with aluminum into its repeating structure.

The hybrid MLD films were explored for their response to stimuli. The electron-responsive properties of both HfO-and ZnO-based MLD hybrid thin films were measured, and the results showed that they have potential as effective electron-beam resists, with possible implications for future extreme ultraviolet (EUV) applications in microelectronics fabrication. Overall, the film synthesis studies were closely integrated with characterization studies that elucidate MLD mechanisms and both microscopic and macroscopic film properties, and may help lead to new approaches to create interfacial functionality for a wide range of systems.

Toward broader impact, the project provided research opportunities and direct mentorship to 4 PhD students, 3 rotation graduate students, and 1 undergraduate student. During the grant reporting period, the PI maintained a diverse research group in which more than 50% of the group’s PhD students, postdocs and undergraduate researchers were women or underrepresented minorities. The results of the research were disseminated in journal publications and conference presentations to the research community. In the area of scientific outreach to the public, the PI promoted women in STEM by taking part in activities such as editorials, journal features, panels, and interviews for video and web spotlights.

Over the reporting period, the PI also served as Vice Provost for Graduate Education and Postdoctoral Affairs at Stanford University. In this role, she supported many activities related to diversity and inclusion in graduate and postdoctoral education, including graduate fellowships and postdoctoral programs aimed at diversifying the professoriate. As Vice Provost, she also helped launch a new graduate fellowship program to allow students to contribute through public service and social impact internships during their doctoral program.

 


Last Modified: 07/11/2024
Modified by: Stacey F Bent
